problem_text:
A group G is said to be a K-group if for every subgroup A ⩽ G there exists a subgroup B ⩽ G such that A ∩ B = 1 and ⟨A, B⟩ = G. Is it true that normal subgroups of K-groups are also K-groups?
M. Emaldi
answer: No, it is not (V. N. Obraztsov, J. Austral. Math. Soc. (Ser. A), 61, no. 2 (1996), 267–288).
